Description: Shoulder fragment of Attic black-figured pottery amphora. Inside reserved; exterior: chariot team to right (remaining are the heads of the two pole horses, and part of the head of the right trace horse); behind the team, a warrior to left (part of his helmet, his shoulder, and his baldric remain); uncertain traces above the horses; added red for the horses' manes, the helmet crest, and the baldric.
Producer name: Attributed to the Circle of: Lydos (Venit)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Circle of Lydos. Compare Athens, Kerameikos 7058 by Lydos (Paralipomena 45-; Tiverios pl.29). Similar is the drawing of the pole horse's jaw, bridle, ear, and wavy line that separates the neck from the mane. The double line typically used by Lydos for the eyebrow, however, is lacking on the fragment in Alexandria, and the manes are red rather than the linear mane preferred by Lydos.'
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 72, no. 235 pl. 53)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0883)
